wikipedia_page.main: Brigadier James Noel Tetley  (30 December 1898 – 25 December 1971) was a member of a prominent Yorkshire brewing family and a senior British Army officer who saw active service in the Italian Campaign during the Second World War.

response: The 25th Tank Brigade came under the command of Brigadier James Noel Tetley of the Leeds Rifles at the end of the Tunisia campaign. He was the only Territorial Army officer of the Royal Tank Regiment to command a brigade on active service. The brigade, including 51 RTR, remained training in North Africa for almost a year, before they were required for service on the Italian Front. The regiment celebrated Cambrai Day (20 November, commemorating the tank Battle of Cambrai) in Algeria.51 RTR War Diary November 1943, The National Archives, file WO 169/9380. 51 RTR embarked on 16 April 1944 and landed at Naples, where it was equipped with Churchill tanks, with a few Shermans and Stuarts.51 RTR War Diary April 1944, The National Archives, file WO 170/865.
*James Noel Tetley (1898–1971), member of Tetley brewing family and Army officer

link_mentions.page: List of honorary graduates of the University of Leeds

response: The 7th and 8th Leeds Rifles were both reformed on 2 February 1920, and the TF was reconstituted as the Territorial Army in 1921. Both battalions continued to serve as part of the 146th (1st West Riding) Infantry Brigade of the 49th (West Riding) Infantry Division. The 7th Battalion was commanded by Lieutenant Colonel Charles Herbert Tetley, who had won a DSO during the war, and his cousin James Noel Tetley was one of the subalterns.Army List 1919, 1924.Kelly's Directory, Leeds 1925.
*1948–1963: Brig. James Noel Tetley, DSO, TD, DL, ADC

The 34th Armoured Brigade had just two commanding officers: Brigadier J. N. TetleyJames Noel Tetley at Generals of WWII. until June 1943 (left to command 25th Tank Brigade) and then Brigadier W. S. Clarke,William Stanhope Clarke at Generals of WWII. who commanded the brigade until it was disbanded in 1946.
